name: hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation | hard coal | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/1177/documentation

This activity describes the mining and preparation of hard coal in China. The activity comprises blasting during site development, mine infrastructure, additional requirements of steel and wood and electricity supply from both an on-site coal power plant, which is fueled with the unprepared raw coal, and from the grid. Emissions comprise both, emissions resulting directly from mine operation and coal preparation as well as emissions from uncontrolled coal fires in China. Please see in the comment of each emission exchange where it stems from. Emissions related to the mine operation and coal preparation were taken over from a previous version of this dataset for which detailed documentation can be found in Dones et al. (2007). Emissions related to uncontrolled coal fires were modeled according to the best available information in 2017. ;Uncontrolled coal fires occur when coal deposits in untapped coal beds, in active or abandoned underground coal mines or in waste dumps of open pit mines ignite. This can happen spontaneously, for example when coal is exposed to oxygen and hot sunlight. Coal fires already occurred in prehistoric times, ignited for example by volcanoes. Today completely spontaneous fires without human involvement are less common (Künzer & Stracher, 2011). Song and Künzer (2014) estimate that Chinese coal fires accounted for 40% of GHG emissions from coal fires in 2002. At that time China also mined about 40% of global hard coal. In absolute terms, van Dijk (2011) estimates that a maximum of 20 million tonnes of coal is burnt in uncontrolled fires in China per year. Song and Künzer (2014) point out that given the investment in firefighting efforts over the past years this number may meanwhile be significantly lower. However, no more recent quantitative estimate is available to confirm that. For other geographies we carefully evaluated the available data and found them insufficient to make reliable estimates. For this reason, China continues to be the only geography in ecoinvent which accounts for the impacts of coal fires in the hard coal mining activity. While this is consistent with previous versions of the database, it is an important improvement in data accuracy. The estimate of 0.33kg CO2/kg of hard coal mined made by Dones et al. (2007) for ecoinvent version 2 relied on meanwhile disproved research which largely overestimated the significance of coal fires. We calculate the current emissions from coal fires based on the conservative estimate of 20Mt lost to such fires each year. This means we relate the current annual rate of burnt coal seams to the current coal production volumes in China and neglect the fact that past mining activities are responsible for the coal burning today, while today’s mining activities will be responsible for emissions occurring in the near to distant future. The combustion is modelled as open burning of the average Chinese coal composition according to USGS’s World Coal Quality Inventory (USGS, 2010).  This means, we assume complete combustion conditions, while a major share of coal actually combusts under a lack of oxygen. Given the current state of knowledge on coal fires we consider this the best available approximation. We are eager to improve it as better data become available in the future. The amount of coal corresponding to the assumed losses of 20Mt/yr has been added to the coal resources consumption.;Methane emissions comprise those resulting from coal fires as well as fugitive methane emissions related to coal mining activities. (See exchange comment "methane, fossil" for more details.);Further modeling choices and assumptions include:;•	In order to enable a consistent calculation of the cumulative energy demand, the extracted mass of raw coal was adjusted by a factor of 1.03, taking into account the difference in the upper heating value of raw coal of this region (19.7 MJ/kg), compared to the used worldwide average of 19.1 MJ/kg.;•	Mine reclamation is not included in this module, because it mostly concerns the tailings, which are described in a separate module. ;•	Electricity, heating from heavy oil industrial boilers, and diesel uses are included. The use of the module "heat, at hard coal industrial furnace 1-10MW" leads to an underestimation of emissions, because the quality of coal burned at mines is usually lower than coal burned in industrial boilers elsewhere. ;•	Water uses in mining and coal washing have been approximately described using the module "tap water". ;•	Radon emissions are recalculated from average value worldwide using the ratio of U content 36/20 from UNSCEAR 1993. ;•	Mining and preparation related emissions to water are estimated for Western European conditions and applied to this region. They are assumed to be released to rivers. Possible emissions to groundwater have not been accounted for.;•	All coalbed methane released from the seam is accounted for as natural gas resource and assumed to be entirely emitted to air. The methane recovered in some major mines, possibly used for own energetic needs and/or district heating, has not been described as an energy byproduct. The unaccounted energy is most likely negligible compared to the energy content of the product coal. ;;Reference(s): ;Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen;von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von;Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die;Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre;for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH;Song, Z., Künzer, C., 2014, Coal fires in China over the last decade: A comprehensive review, International Journal of Coal Geology, Volume 133, 1 November 2014, Pages 72-99, https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0166516214001906;Kuenzer, C., Stracher, G., 2011. Geomorphology of coal seam fires. Geomorphology 209–222, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.geomorph.2011.09.004.;USGS, 2010, World Coal Quality Inventory, Chemical Data for China retrieved from Chttps://eerscmap.usgs.gov/wocqi/resources/countries/China_WOCQI_chemical_data.xlsx, 1.March 2018

This activity starts with the extraction of raw coal from ground. It includes the electricity, heat, and diesel requirements, pumped groundwater, explosives and solid wastes related to coal mining and preparation activities in China. Emissions to air, water and soil, compromise the emissions directly from mining activities as well as emissions from uncontrolled coal fires.

This activity ends with the preparation of the mined coal to the quality demanded by the consumers. Not included is recovered methane. Specific processes for this CN dataset are: electricity supply from local coal power plant and grid (CN); blasting, steel, and wood requirements.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Some data taken over from previous versions of this dataset are region specific (Shanxi Province and county-wide).
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Most data related to the mining and preparation activities relies on literature from the 1990ies.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Emissions from uncontrolled coal fires in China are modeled as complete combustion of an average composition of Chinese coal. The estimated current annual rate of burnt coal seams is related to the current coal production volumes in China.

flow.name: hard coal
flow.category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

exchanges.description: Emissions from uncontrolled coal fires: These emissions were modeled under the assumption of 20Mt hard coal burnt under full combustion conditions (open burning) in coal seam fires per year using an averaged composition of Chinese coals reported by USGS’s World Coal Quality Inventory (USGS, 2010), average carbon content of 0.635.

exchanges.description:
Methane emissions are a sum of emissions from uncontrolled coal fires and fugitive emissions from mining, processing, storage and transportation of coal.
CH4 emissions from uncontrolled fires: 
These emissions were modeled under the assumption of 20Mt hard coal burnt under full combustion conditions (open burning) in coal seam fires per year using an averaged composition of Chinese coals reported by USGS’s World Coal Quality Inventory (USGS, 2010) (average carbon content of 0.635). Mind that actual combustion conditions for coal burning in uncontrolled fires are likely to result in incomplete combustion, which would cause lower CO2 emissions than assumed here, while CO and CH4 emissions would likely be higher. (For more details see “general comment”-field of this dataset.)
Fugitive CH4 emissions:
These emissions are calculated based on the average emission factors for mine operation and post-mining activities of underground and surface coal mines suggested by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories (Chapter 4.1 Fugitive emissions from mining, processing, storage and transportation of coal, p. 4.11 ff., accessible at <https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/pdf/2_Volume2/V2_4_Ch4_Fugitive_Emissions.pdf>, July 2018).
Average CH4 emission factors according to IPCC 2006 are:
underground coal production = 18m3/tonne = 12.06 kg/tonne
post-mining emissions, underground mines = 2.5m3/tonne = 1.675 kg/tonne
surface coal production = 1.2m3/tonne = 0.804 kg/tonne
post mining emissions, surface mines = 0.1m3/tonne =0.067 kg/tonne
Ch4 density at 20 degrees Celsius and 1 bar is 0.67kg/m3.
The applied share of coal from underground and surface mines in China is 95 % and 5 %, respectively (Bian et al., 2010).
Under this approach the calculated CH4 emissions in China amount to 0.013 kg CH4/kg coal. Uncertainty of this value is high. Nonetheless, this approach was considered preferable by industry experts over the estimated fugitive CH4 emissions from soild fuels in China in2012, published in the UNFCCC database for “Greenhouse Gas Inventory Data - Detailed data by Party” (This source reports a total of 23847000 tonnes fugitive CH4 emissions from solid fuels in 2012. This would result in specific fugitive methane emission of 0.0065kg CH4/kg coal considering 2012 production volume (VDKi, 2017)). The reasons for this choice is mostly that no documentation is available for the UNFCCC 2012 value, which does not allow to evaluate underlying assumptions and uncertainties.
Reference(s):
Zhengfu BIAN, Hilary I INYANG, John L DANIELS, Frank OTTO, Sue STRUTHERS, 2010, Environmental issues from coal mining and their solutions, Mining Science and Technology (China), Volume 20, Issue 2, Pages 215-223, ISSN 1674-5264, <https://doi.org/10.1016/S1674-5264(09)60187-3>.
IPCC, 2006, IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories, Chapter 4.1 Fugitive emissions from mining, processing, storage and transportation of coal, p. 4.11 ff., accessible at <https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/pdf/2_Volume2/V2_4_Ch4_Fugitive_Emissions.pdf>, July 2018
UNFCCC, 2018, Greenhouse Gas Inventory Data - Detailed data by Party, data retrieved online from <http://di.unfccc.int/detailed_data_by_party> on 19.07.2018, Party: China, Inventory: All years, Category: 1.B Fugitive Emissions from Fuels, Gas: CH4, 1.B1 Solid Fuels in Last Reported year (2012): 23,847.00 Gg
Verein der Kohleimporteure (VDKi). 2017. Jahresbericht 2017. Accessed online at: http://www.kohlenimporteure.de/publikationen/jahresbericht-2017.html, 28.11.2016
